title: Manhattan Luxury Home Deals on Track For Slowest Third Quarter in 7 Years
text:
A dozen Manhattan homes asking $4 million or more went into contract in the week ending Sunday, as a new tax hike on multi-million-dollar sales in the city continues to weigh on the market, according to a report Monday from Olshan Realty.



More: Rising Rents, Wary Buyers Means Now Might Be the Time to Buy an Investment Property

At this rate, total pending sales in the borough—a global hub for luxury real estate—are on track for the slowest third quarter since 2012, according to the weekly round-up. A progressive mansion tax on home sales over $2 million that went into effect on July 1 is largely blamed for the steep slowdown in agreed-to sales.



Since the tax went into effect, pending deals over $4 million are down 27% compared to the same period last year, according to Olshan’s calculation.



Meanwhile, total sales last week rang in at $80.81 million, about $12 million higher than the week prior but still fairly anemic for this time of year.



The most expensive deal last week was a triplex condo in a historic building on the Upper West Side, asking $12.8 million.



The nearly 5,000-square-foot home—which includes five bedrooms and a garden terrace—is located in the former St. Agnes Boys High School, a landmarked Beaux-Arts building that developers Tamarkin Co. and CL Investment Group are converting into 13 homes, called 555 West End Avenue.

The second most expensive home in Manhattan to find a buyer was a condo, asking $10.495 million, at the riverside Tribeca development 70 Vestry St. The nearly 3,000-square-foot apartment at the Robert A.M. Stern-designed building faces the Hudson River and has three bedrooms.
